Detailed Description

The class H represents Hamilton's quaternions.

These are numbers of the form where are real and satisfy .

Author:
Edward Scheinerman

Definition at line 56 of file quaternions.h.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

H::H (  R  aa = 0.,
R  bb = 0.,
R  cc = 0.,
R  dd = 0.
)  [inline]
 

This constructor sets the a,b,c,d components of the quaternion.

Using fewer than four arguments is permissible as missing values are interpresented as zero.

Parameters:
aa real part
bb coefficient of i
cc coefficient of j
dd coefficient of k

Definition at line 71 of file quaternions.h.

H::H (  C  z  )  [inline]
 

This single argument constructor converts a complex number into a quaterion.

The real part of the argument becomes the real part of the quaterion and the complex part of the argument becomse the coefficient of i.

Parameters:
z a complex number

Definition at line 188 of file quaternions.h.

R H::norm (   )  const [inline]
 

The norm of this quaternion.

Note: No absolute value method or procedure is defined in this file (to avoid the need to include cmath). It is easy enough to create your own absolute value procedure like this: 

 #include "quaternions.h"
 #include <cmath>
 R abs(H x) { 
    return sqrt(x.norm());
 }

Returns:

Definition at line 225 of file quaternions.h.

bool H::operator< (  const H &  that  )  const [inline]
 

Less-than operator.

The purpose of this operator is to allow STL containers (such as set) to be able to hold objects of type H. The order is lexicographic
